section.title: Overview
section.para: Exact methods will always find the global optimum and recognize it too. That being said, they don't scale (not even beyond toy data sets) and are therefore mostly useless.

section.title: Algorithm description

section.title: Algorithm description
section.para: Depth-First Search is an improvement over Brute Force, as it regularly prunes away an entire subset of solutions which cannot have a better solution than the best solution already found at that point. for example: at index 15, it can prune away all unvisited solutions with queen A on row 0, because none will be better than the solution of index 14 with a score of -1.

Notice that it (much like Brute Force) creates a search tree that explodes as the problem size increases. Depth-First Search is mostly unusable for a real-world NP-complete problem due to time limitations.
Technically, this Backtracking Depth-First Search with pruning is a form of Branch And Bound, although Branch and Bound is often more flexible in its pruning.
